headline: Kimberly Yee drops out of Arizona governor's race, will run for reelection as treasurer
author: Stacey Barchenger
sentences:
Lawmaker fined $62K for not disclosing donors, pays $1K Arizona could take oversight of toxic coal waste disposal Election deniers file lawsuit to ban machines Biggs said to push early for alternate electors
And although the race to replace Ducey is already poised to break spending records eight months before voters cast their ballots, Yee fell behind other GOP hopefuls.

The decision by Yee to end her bid leaves four leading GOP candidates for governor: Steve Gaynor, a businessman; Karrin Taylor-Robson, a developer and former member of the Arizona Board of Regents; Lake, the former Fox 10 anchor; and Matt Salmon, the former congressman and lobbyist for Arizona State University.

State Sen. David Livingston of Peoria had been in the running, but he dropped out of the treasurer's race on Dec. 23, citing an "opportunity in the private sector" that wouldn't allow for a year-round elected position, a statement on his website reads.

Yee pledged to use a second term in office to battle the Biden administration, which Republicans nationwide have blamed for a surge in inflation and "continues to lead the country towards a disastrous, economic downturn."
Yee was the first major Republican candidate to announce her bid for governor, but she faced a bruising primary race with several high-profile challengers battling for voters' attention.
Yee made headlines in September for selling off the state's shares in the ice cream company Ben & Jerry's parent, Unilever, saying the company was engaged in a boycott of Israel.
Arizona Treasurer Kimberly Yee announced Saturday she was dropping out of the race for governor and instead would seek a second term as the state's chief investment officer.
"I want to thank my volunteers and supporters from across Arizona's 15 counties for their support during my campaign for governor," Yee said in a statement.
"I welcome Kimberly Yee to the race for state treasurer after she realized she would be outgunned in another statewide race," Weninger said in a statement.
Doug Ducey in January 2023, and her decision to seek a second four-year term as treasurer adds another twist to that race's Republican primary.
Corrections & Clarifications: An earlier version of the article included incorrect information about state Sen. David Livingston's candidacy.
"I am proud of this historic record growth under my watch, which means less taxes and more money for Arizonans," Yee said.
Brandon Hiller, Yee's campaign spokesperson, said Saturday that Yee had raised about $504,000, with $230,000 cash on hand.
"I remain committed to the treasurer's race to ensure there is a good steward overseeing the state's investments."
Yee said the value of the state's invested assets had gained $11 billion in the three years she's been in office.
"I have transformed this office on a platform of financial education, growth and prosperity across the state."
"As I transition my campaign, I invite them to join me in my re-election efforts for Arizona treasurer."
That left Yee at the back of the pack when it came to fundraising, in some cases by millions of dollars.
Livingston said he would instead seek an open seat in the state House of Representatives.

Ducey served as treasurer from 2011 to 2015 before becoming the state's chief executive.
Yee will face sitting state lawmaker Rep. Jeff Weninger of Chandler for the nomination.
Yee struggled to stand out in a crowded field of GOP candidates hoping to replace Gov.
First elected in 2018, Yee is the first Asian American to hold statewide office.
One, Kari Lake, received a key endorsement from former President Donald Trump.
She had hoped to follow Ducey's path to the governor's office.
He is now running for the Arizona House of Representatives.
